comments.author: lisaiscooking
comments.content: First, I couldn't be more jealous of your local chanterelles! And, second, the red wine sauce sounds fantastic.

comments.author: maybellesmom
comments.content: Oh, this is heavenly looking.

comments.author: Ivys Manning
comments.content: I love how I have to look twice at the photo, cuz my cheffy brain just ASSUMES there's a sausage in that heady mix somewhere. Don't need it with good chanterelles, though, do you? Lovely, this.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Thanks Ivy! The chanterelles really do provide a lot of "meatiness", for
lack of a better word. Actually, I really do need a better word for that
quality. Anyone?

comments.author: veggie wedgie
comments.content: Holy Yuminess! You could say the mushrooms add "richness"!?

comments.author: arugulove
comments.content: You always make such beautiful dishes.  This looks perfect for fall.

comments.author: John - Mormon Foodie
comments.content: Mushroom burgundy. The rosemary is a perfect choice of herb for this. Very nice, Michael.

comments.author: Megan
comments.content: Oh, darn it -- I wanted the preserved lemon recipe!  I just made my first batch of preserved lemons (oh my god, why did it take me 30 years to discover that these existed???), and I'm just slowly learning how to use them to cook with.

comments.author: TasteHongKong
comments.content: You have turned the usual into unusual, nice idea!

comments.author: Cheese Recipe
comments.content: That's a great vegetarian recipe! Thanks for the yummy potato recipe.

comments.author: Sarah
comments.content: This is one of those dishes that makes me praise heaven that there is someone out there who knows that vegetarians eat things other than lettuce. This looks SO good, I can practically smell it now.

comments.author: The Hungry Mouse
comments.content:
Chanterelles have to be one of the best foods on the planet! Looks great. :D

+Jessie

comments.author: cordelia810
comments.content: I think the "5th" Taste and perhaps a suitable substitute description for "meatiness" would be Umami.  Any thoughts on this?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Cordelia - I was speaking more of the texture, but flavor wise, yes, umami is indeed the right word.

comments.author: Ryan
comments.content: I just made it - fantastic.  We live out in Oregon and a friend picked some fresh from the woods for us.  I changed it up a bit, using olive oil on the pan instead of butter - overall I used less butter, just for a healthier version, only adding a little butter for the sauce at the end.  Excellent recipe, highly recommended.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks, Ryan! I'm glad it was a hit and I'm sure it is good with part olive oil too. Man, if I had any chanterelles I'd go cook up a batch of that right now.

comments.author: Amelia Bjesse-Puffin
comments.content: I'm really excited to try this recipe. I'm going to use earth balance instead of butter, so we'll see how that is.  But I've been vegan so long, I don't even remember what butter tastes like!  =)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I've never used Earth Balance for this, but a quick web search shows people using it in "beurre" blanc applications with success, so I suspect it will work fine. Let us know how it turns out!

comments.author: Shira
comments.content: This was just about one of the best tasting meals I have ever had.  It felt entirely decadent and scrumptious.  Thank you!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Good deal! Thanks for taking the time to comment.

comments.author: swarna mani
comments.content: Prepared this today for the second...A recipe that makes me go to it again and again

comments.author: swarna mani
comments.content:
Actually I was about to type "for the second time"...but it got posted without time in it...we just had this for our dinner.
It is a wonderful vegetarian entrée.

comments.author: Parveen Choudhary
comments.content:
Thanks fantastic recipe. Tommorrow i am going to try it out.

Parveen

comments.author: John
comments.content: This was great. There are no chanterelles around here just now, so I used crimini, cut in halves (or quarters for the slightly larger ones). And I discovered, 3/4 of the way through cooking, that I didn't actually have that leftover red wine that I THOUGHT I had. Solution: replace the wine with a semi-dark beer. Turned out wonderful. If I were to make another change, it'd be to about double the shallots -- they were good, but there were too few to balance the potatoes. Of course, I didn't actually measure anything, so maybe I had too many potatoes to start with. :)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Nice! Your adaptations sound good. Using beer in the sauce reminds me of this dish: https://herbivoracious.com//2010/06/crisp-polenta-with-braised-cabbage-and-beans-recipe.html .

comments.author: Kim
comments.content: Does this have to be served with something like say white or brown rice?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: No, I wouldn't serve it with a grain. I think the potatoes already serve as a starchy element.

comments.author: Hanna
comments.content: This looks fantastic!  Can't wait to lay my hands on some chanterelles!

comments.author: Carrie
comments.content:
I can't describe how I felt while eating this -- it was one of those out-of-body, one-with-the-blissful-deliciousness-of-the-universe experiences.  I could easily have eaten every bite but managed to restrain myself and am enjoying the anticipation of a second sensory inundation!

Another reason to love chanterelles!
